Diagram 878
\begin{quote}
\textbf{Purity correspondence assumption.} \index{purity correspondence assumption} We have the following
\begin{description}
\item \textit{Pure preparations.}
 Pure system preparations, $\mathsf{A}^{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}$, correspond to rank one operators, $\hat{A}^{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}=|A\rangle^{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}\negsh\langle A|$ (where $|A\rangle^{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}$ is not necessarily normalised to $1$).   Furthermore, all appropriately normalised rank one operators, $\hat{A}^{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}=|A\rangle^{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}\negsh\langle A|$, have a pure preparation, $\mathsf{A}^{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}$, that they correspond to.
\item \textit{Pure results.}
Similarly, pure system results, $\mathsf{C}_{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}$, correspond to rank one operators, $\hat{C}_{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}=|C\rangle_{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}\negss\langle C|$ (where, again, $|C\rangle_{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}$ is not necessarily normalised to $1$). Furthermore, all appropriately normalised rank one operators, $\hat{C}_{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}=|C\rangle_{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}\negs\langle C|$, have a pure result, $\mathsf{C}_{\mathsfs{a}^+_1}$, that they correspond to.
\end{description}
\end{quote}

Diagrams 55 (many isometry mirror equations)
We will illustrate these remarks with the equation that defines isometry (to be discussed in Sec.\ \ref{sec:isometriesandcoisometries}).   Thus, consider the equation
\begin{equation} \label{leftisometrydefnearlier}
\begin{Compose}{0}{0} \setdefaultfont{}\setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\crectangledleft[-1]{U}{1}{1.5}{0,-3}\csymbol{V} \crectangledleft[1]{UA}{1}{1.5}{0,3}\csymbol{V}
\thispoint{d}{0,-7}\thispoint{u}{0,7}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{U}{0} \csymbolalt{a}
\jointbleft[left]{U}{0}{UA}{0} \csymbolalt{b}
\jointbleft[left]{UA}{0}{u}{0} \csymbolalt{a}
\end{Compose}
~~=~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{}\setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\thispoint{d}{0,-7}\thispoint{u}{0,7}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{u}{0} \csymbolalt{a}
\end{Compose}
\end{equation}
This can be written in mirror form as
\begin{equation}\label{isometrymirrorconditionearlier}
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\crectangledleft[-1]{B}{1}{1.5}{0,0} \csymbol{V}
\thispoint{d}{0,-4} \cmirrordown{u}{2}{0,4}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{B}{0} \csymbolalt{a} \jointbleft[left]{B}{0}{u}{0}\csymbolalt{b}
\end{Compose}
~~=~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\thispoint{d}{0,-4} \cmirrordown{u}{2}{0,4}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{u}{0} \csymbolalt{a}
\end{Compose}
\end{equation}
We can apply rotation to get four equivalent equations as follows
\begin{equation}\label{fourmirrorequations}
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\crectangledleft[-1]{B}{1}{1.5}{0,0} \csymbol{V}
\thispoint{d}{0,-4} \cmirrordown{u}{2}{0,4}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{B}{0} \csymbolalt{a} \jointbleft[left]{B}{0}{u}{0}\csymbolalt{b}
\end{Compose}
~~=~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\thispoint{d}{0,-4} \cmirrordown{u}{2}{0,4}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{u}{0} \csymbolalt{a}
\end{Compose}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\crectangledleft[-1]{B}{1}{1.5}{0,0} \csymbol{V}
\thispoint{d}{0,-4} \cmirrorleft{M}{2}{3,5}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{B}{0} \csymbolalt{a}
\relpoint{B}{0,3}{Bup}
\jointbleft[left]{B}{0}{Bup}{0}\csymbolalt{b}
\jointlnoarrow{Bup}{0}{M}{0}
\end{Compose}
~~=~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\thispoint{d}{0,-4} \cmirrorleft{M}{2}{3,5}
\thispoint{u}{0,3}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{u}{0} \csymbolalt{a}
\jointlnoarrow{u}{0}{M}{0}
\end{Compose}
\end{equation}
\begin{equation}\label{fourmirrorequationstwo}
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\crectangledleft[-1]{B}{1}{1.5}{0,0} \csymbol{V}
\thispoint{d}{0,-4} \cmirrorright{M}{2}{-3,5}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{B}{0} \csymbolalt{a}
\relpoint{B}{0,3}{Bup}
\jointbleft[left]{B}{0}{Bup}{0}\csymbolalt{b}
\jointrnoarrow{Bup}{0}{M}{0}
\end{Compose}
~~=~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\thispoint{d}{0,-4} \cmirrorright{M}{2}{-3,5}
\thispoint{u}{0,3}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{u}{0} \csymbolalt{a}
\jointrnoarrow{u}{0}{M}{0}
\end{Compose}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\crectangledleft[-1]{B}{1}{1.5}{0,0} \csymbol{V}
\thispoint{d}{0,-4} \cmirrorup{M}{2}{3,-6}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{B}{0} \csymbolalt{a}

\thispoint{u}{0,3}
\jointbleft[left]{B}{0}{u}{0}\csymbolalt{b}
\jointtnoarrow{u}{0}{u}{3}
\jointbright{M}{0}{u}{3}
\end{Compose}
~~=~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\thispoint{d}{0,-4} \cmirrorup{M}{2}{3,-6}
\thispoint{u}{0,3}
\jointbleft[left]{d}{0}{u}{0} \csymbolalt{a}
\jointtnoarrow{u}{0}{u}{3}
\jointbright{M}{0}{u}{3}
\end{Compose}
\end{equation}
Note how the point at which the wire is attached to the mirror is \lq\lq dragged" as the mirror is rotated.

We can replace the mirrors with twist mirrors to get four more equations.  Further, we can apply conjupositions which can move the square dot to each of its four locations and flip $B$ from being a left to being a right object (or leave it as a left object).  For example, we the following four equations are also equivalent to \eqref{isometrymirrorconditionearlier}:
\begin{equation}\label{fourmirrorequationssmoke}
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}
\crectangledright[+2]{B}{1}{1.5}{0,0} \csymbol{V}
\thispoint{d}{0,-4} \cmirrordownsmoke{u}{2}{0,4}
\jointbright[right]{d}{0}{B}{0} \csymbolalt{a} \jointbright[right]{B}{0}{u}{0}\csymbolalt{b}
\end{Compose}
~~=~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setdefaultfont{} \setsecondfont{\mathsfs}

We can gauge fix the $\gamma$'s so that the physical nonconjugating transformations give the same answer as the standard nonconjugating transformations.  To do this we can put
\begin{equation}
\gamma^\mathsfs{a}=\gamma_\lowsub{\mathsfs{a}}=\frac{1}{{N}_\mathsfs{a}^{\frac{1}{4}}}
\end{equation}
(for each system type) which satisfies \eqref{gammanormalisationcondition}.  Then the special caps, cups, and twists are equal to the (standard) caps, cups, and twists.  We will not employ this in what follows since it obscures the gauge freedom we have and, potentially, hides some interesting physics.


\begin{equation}\label{horizontaltransposeconversionfactor}
\kappa_\lowsub{\mathsfs{a}}^\mathsfs{b}\left[\text{L to R}, H
%\extrightarrow{\text{L to R}}
\rightarrow
\utilde{H}\right]
=
\frac{\overline{\gamma}^\mathsfs{b} \overline{\gamma}_\lowsub{\mathsfs{a}}}
{\gamma^\mathsfs{b}\gamma_\lowsub{\mathsfs{a}} }
\end{equation}


\begin{equation}\label{verticaladjointconversionfactor}
\kappa_\lowsub{\mathsfs{a}}^\mathsfs{b}\left[\overline{V}\rightarrow \utilde{\overline{V}}\right]=\frac{\gamma_\lowsub{\mathsfs{b}} \gamma^\mathsfs{a}  }{\overline{\gamma}^\mathsfs{b}\overline{\gamma}_\lowsub{\mathsfs{a}} }
\end{equation}

If we use the time forward formalism, we calculate probabilities for outcome readouts conditioned on incomes:
\begin{equation}   \text{prob}(\text{outcomes}|\text{incomes}) \end{equation}
If we use the time symmetric formalism, we calculate joint probabilities over incomes and outcomes.
\begin{equation}   \text{prob}(\text{incomes},\text{outcomes}) \end{equation}
We can use the time symmetric formalism to calculate the probability of the incomes where we ignore outcomes
\begin{equation}  \text{prob}(\text{incomes}) \end{equation}
This was done in the example in Sec.\ \ref{sec:circuitsinthetimeforwardcase} (see \eqref{probxyx}).

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Purity correspondence assumption.} We have the following
\begin{description}
\item \textit{Pure preparations.}
 Pure system preparations, $\mathsf{A}^{\mathsfs{a}_1}$, correspond to rank one operators, $\hat{A}^{\mathsfs{a}_1}=|A\rangle^{\mathsfs{a}_1}\langle A|$ (where $|A\rangle_{\mathsfs{a}_1}$ is not necessarily normalised).   Furthermore, all appropriately normalised rank one operators, $\hat{A}^{\mathsfs{a}_1}=|A\rangle^{\mathsfs{a}_1}\langle A|$, have a pure preparation, $\mathsf{A}^{\mathsfs{a}_1}$, that they correspond to.
\item \textit{Pure results.}
Similarly, pure system results, $\mathsf{C}_{\mathsfs{a}_1}$, correspond to rank one operators, $\hat{C}_{\mathsfs{a}_1}=|C\rangle_{\mathsfs{a}_1}\langle C|$ (where, again, $|C\rangle_{\mathsfs{a}_1}$ is not necessarily normalised). Furthermore, all appropriately normalised rank one operators, $\hat{C}_{\mathsfs{a}_1}=|C\rangle_{\mathsfs{a}_1}\langle C|$, have a pure result, $\mathsf{C}_{\mathsfs{a}_1}$, that they correspond to.
\end{description}
\end{quote}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Maximal representation theorem.}  Any operator, $\hat{B}$, can be written as
\begin{equation}\label{maximalrepofBcomplex}
\begin{Compose}{0}{0} \setsecondfont{\mathsfc}\setthirdfont{\mathttc}
\Ccircledouble{B}{1.5}{0,0} \relpoint{B}{45:5}{Ba}  \relpoint{B}{-135:5}{Bx}
\joincc[above left]{B}{45}{Ba}{-135}  \csymbolalt{a}
\joinccthick[above left]{B}{-135}{Bx}{45} \csymbolthird{x}
\end{Compose}
~~=~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0} \setdefaultfont{\mathsfb} \setsecondfont{\mathsfc}\setthirdfont{\mathttc}
\ccircledouble{B}{1.5}{0,0} \csymbolnorm{\physicalise{\mathsf{B}}} \relpoint{B}{45:5}{Ba}
\ccircledouble{X}{1.2}{-135:5}  \csymbolnorm{\maxresultsfb{X}}
\joincc[above left]{B}{45}{Ba}{-135}  \csymbolalt{a}
\joincc[above left]{B}{-135}{X}{45} \csymbolalt{x}
\relpoint{X}{-135:5}{Xx}
\joinccthick[above left]{X}{-135}{Xx}{45} \csymbolthird{x}
\end{Compose}
\end{equation}
where
\begin{equation}\label{physicaliseBcomplex}
\begin{Compose}{0}{0} \setsecondfont{\mathsfc}\setthirdfont{\mathttc}
\ccircledouble{B}{1.5}{0,0} \csymbol{\physicalise{B}} \relpoint{B}{45:5}{Ba}  \relpoint{B}{-135:5}{Bx}
\joincc[above left]{B}{45}{Ba}{-135}  \csymbolalt{a}
\joincc[above left]{B}{-135}{Bx}{45} \csymbolalt{x}
\end{Compose}
~~:=~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0} \setdefaultfont{\mathsfb} \setsecondfont{\mathsfc}\setthirdfont{\mathttc}

\ccircledouble{X}{1.2}{-135:5}  \csymbolnorm{\maxprepsfb{X}}
\joincc[above left]{B}{45}{Ba}{-135}  \csymbolalt{a}
\joinccthick[above left]{B}{-135}{X}{45} \csymbolthird{x}
\relpoint{X}{-135:5}{Xx}
\joincc[above left]{X}{-135}{Xx}{45} \csymbolalt{x}
\end{Compose}
\end{equation}
Further, the following statements hold: (i) If $\hat{B}$ is $T$-positive then $\physicalise{\hat{B}}$ is $T$-positive.
(ii) If $\hat{B}$ satisfies simple double causality then $\physicalise{\hat{B}}$ satisfies simple double causality.  (iii) If $\hat{B}$ is physical and the synchronous partition with simple double causality assumption (see Sec.\ \ref{sec:synchronousassumptionwithDC}) holds then $\physicalise{\hat{B}}$ is physical.
\end{quote}

\end{Compose}

\begin{equation}

\begin{Compose}{0}{0} \setdefaultfont{\mathopbold}\setsecondfont{\mathsfc}\setthirdfont{\mathttc}

\ccircledouble{I}{1.3}{105:6} \csymbol{I}\joincc[above right]{B}{105}{I}{-75}  \csymbolalt[0,0]{s}

\end{equation}

\end{quote}

$\hat{\boldsymbol{B}}$ $\boldsymbol{\hat{B}}$

This operator tensor is an element of the space
\begin{equation}
\mathcal{V}_{\mathsfc{a}_1}\otimes \mathcal{V}_{\mathsfc{c}_2} \otimes \mathcal{P}_{\mathttc{x}_3} \otimes \mathcal{V}^{\mathsfc{b}_4} \otimes \mathcal{P}^{\mathttc{y}_5}
\end{equation}
Here $\mathcal{V}_{\mathsfc{a}_1}$ is the space of Hermitian operators acting on a Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}_{\mathsfc{a}_1}= \mathcal{H}_{\mathsfc{a}^+_1}\otimes\mathcal{H}_{\mathsfc{a}^-_1}$ of dimension $N^\mathsfc{a}=N_{\mathsfc{a}^+}N_{\mathsfc{a}^-}$.  Similarly, $\mathcal{V}^{\mathsfc{b}_4}$ is the space of Hermitian operators acting on a Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}^{\mathsfc{b}_4}= \mathcal{H}^{\mathsfc{b}^+_4}\otimes\mathcal{H}^{\mathsfc{b}^-_4}$ of dimension $N^\mathsfc{a}=N_{\mathsfc{b}^+}N_{\mathsfc{b}^-}$.  Further, $\mathcal{P}_{\mathttc{x}_3}$ is a real vector space of dimension $N_\mathttc{x}$ and $\mathcal{P}^{\mathttc{y}_4}$ is a real vector space of dimension $N_\mathttc{y}$.  Note that superscripts correspond to the direction of the arrows (and these are conventional). In the case that there are no inputs or outputs we will omit the hat over the $A$ symbol.

\begin{Compose}{0}{0} \setdefaultfont{\mathopbold}\setsecondfont{\mathsfc}\setthirdfont{\mathttc}
\Ccircledouble{B}{1.5}{0,0}
\ccircledouble{R}{1.3}{70:4.5} \csymbolfourth{\boldsymbol{R}^+}
\ccircledouble{I}{1.3}{110:4.5} \csymbolfourth{\mathopbold{I}^+}
\relpoint{B}{110:8}{b} \relpoint{B}{70:8}{y}
\relpoint{B}{-105:3.5}{x} \csymbolthird[0,-20]{x} \relpoint{B}{-75:3.5}{a} \csymbolalt[0,-20]{a}
\joincc[left]{B}{110}{I}{-70} \csymbolalt[-10,-5]{b}
\joinccthick[right]{B}{70}{R}{-110} \csymbolthird[10,-5]{y}
\joincc[left]{I}{110}{b}{-70}  \csymbolfourth[-10,-5]{\mathsfc{b}^-}
\joinccthick[right]{R}{70}{y}{-110}   \csymbolfourth[10,5]{\mathttc{y}^-}
\joinccthick{B}{-105}{x}{75}  \joincc{B}{-75}{a}{105}
\end{Compose}
~~~ \equiv ~~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0} \setdefaultfont{\mathopbold}\setsecondfont{\mathsfc}\setthirdfont{\mathttc}
\ccircledouble{B}{1.8}{0,0}  \csymbolfourth{\mathopbold{B}\negs[\negs\negs p^- \negs\negs]}
\ccircledouble{R}{1}{75:4.5} \csymbolfourth{\boldsymbol{R}}
\ccircledouble{I}{1}{105:4.5} \csymbolfourth{\mathopbold{I}}
\relpoint{B}{105:8}{b} \relpoint{B}{75:8}{y}
\relpoint{B}{-105:3.5}{x} \csymbolthird[0,-20]{x} \relpoint{B}{-75:3.5}{a} \csymbolalt[0,-20]{a}
%\joincc[left]{B}{105}{I}{-75} \csymbolalt[-10,-5]{b}
%\joinccthick[right]{B}{75}{R}{-105} \csymbolthird[10,-5]{y}
\joincc[left]{I}{105}{b}{-75}  \csymbolfourth[-10,-5]{\mathsfc{b}^-}
\joinccthick[right]{R}{75}{y}{-105}   \csymbolfourth[10,5]{\mathttc{y}^-}
\joinccthick{B}{-105}{x}{75}  \joincc{B}{-75}{a}{105}
\end{Compose}
\end{equation}
and the \emph{backward causality} condition
\begin{equation}\label{backwardcausalitycomplex}
\begin{Compose}{0}{0} \setdefaultfont{\mathopbold}\setsecondfont{\mathsfc}\setthirdfont{\mathttc}
\Ccircledouble{B}{1.5}{0,0}
\ccircledouble{R}{1.3}{-110:4.5} \csymbolfourth{\boldsymbol{R}^-}
\ccircledouble{I}{1.3}{-70:4.5} \csymbolfourth{\mathopbold{I}^-}
\relpoint{B}{105:3.5}{b} \csymbolalt[0,20]{b} \relpoint{B}{75:3.5}{y} \csymbolthird[0,20]{y}
\relpoint{B}{-110:8}{x} \relpoint{B}{-70:8}{a}
\joincc[right]{B}{-70}{I}{110} \csymbolalt[10,5]{a}
\joinccthick[left]{B}{-110}{R}{70} \csymbolthird[-10,5]{x}
\joincc[right]{I}{-70}{a}{110}  \csymbolfourth[10,5]{\mathsfc{a}^+}
\joinccthick[left]{R}{-110}{x}{70}   \csymbolfourth[-10,5]{\mathttc{x}^+}
\joinccthick{B}{75}{y}{-105}  \joincc{B}{105}{b}{-75}
\end{Compose}
~~~ \equiv ~~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0} \setdefaultfont{\mathopbold}\setsecondfont{\mathsfc}\setthirdfont{\mathttc}
\ccircledouble{B}{1.8}{0,0} \csymbolfourth{\mathopbold{B}\negs[\negs\negs p^+ \negs\negs]}
\ccircledouble{R}{1}{-105:4.5} \csymbolfourth{\boldsymbol{R}}
\ccircledouble{I}{1}{-75:4.5} \csymbolfourth{\mathopbold{I}}
\relpoint{B}{105:3.5}{b} \csymbolalt[0,20]{b} \relpoint{B}{75:3.5}{y} \csymbolthird[0,20]{y}
\relpoint{B}{-105:8}{x} \relpoint{B}{-75:8}{a}
%\joincc[right]{I}{105}{B}{-75} \csymbolalt[10,5]{a}
%\joinccthick[left]{R}{75}{B}{-105} \csymbolthird[-10,5]{x}
\joincc[right]{I}{-75}{a}{105}  \csymbolfourth[10,5]{\mathsfc{a}^+}
\joinccthick[left]{R}{-105}{x}{75}   \csymbolfourth[-10,5]{\mathttc{x}^+}
\joinccthick{B}{75}{y}{-105}  \joincc{B}{105}{b}{-75}
\end{Compose}
\end{equation}

\begin{quote}
\emph{Forward maximality} is the property that, for each pointer type, $\mathtt x$, we can associate a physical type $\mathsfb x$ such that there exist operations
\begin{equation}\label{maximaloperations}
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setthirdfont{\mathsfb}\setsecondfont{\mathtt}
\Crectangle{X}{0.8}{0.8}{0,0}
\cxpreselectincome{X}{0}{x}
\thispoint{p}{0,3} \csymbolthird[0,20]{x} \jointbnoarrow[left]{X}{0}{p}{0}
%\thispoint{pp}{-3,0} \csymbolalt[-20,0]{x} \joinlrnoarrowthick{X}{0}{pp}{0}
\end{Compose}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setsecondfont{\mathtt}\setthirdfont{\mathsfb}
\Crectangle{X}{0.8}{0.8}{0,3}
\thispoint{p}{0,0} \csymbolthird[0,-20]{x} \jointbnoarrow[left]{p}{0}{X}{0}
\thispoint{pp}{3,3} \csymbolalt[20,0]{x} \joinlrnoarrowthick[left]{pp}{0}{X}{0}
\end{Compose}
\end{equation}
for which we have the equivalence
\begin{equation}\label{forwardmaximality}
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setsecondfont{\mathtt} \setthirdfont{\mathsfb}
\Crectangle{X}{0.8}{0.8}{0,-2}
% \relpoint{X}{-4,0}{XL} \csymbolalt[-20,0]{x} \joinrlnoarrowthick{XL}{0}{X}{0}
\crectangle{Y}{0.8}{0.8}{0,2}\csymbol{X} \relpoint{Y}{4,0}{YR}
\cxpreselectincome{X}{0}{x}
%\csymbolalt[20,0]{x}
\joinlrnoarrowthick{YR}{0}{Y}{0}  \csymbolalt[0,5]{x}
\jointbnoarrow[left]{X}{0}{Y}{0} \csymbolthird[0,5]{x}
\end{Compose}
~~~~\equiv ~~~~~~~
\begin{Compose}{0}{0}\setsecondfont{\mathtt}
\thispoint{X}{0,0}
\cxpreselectincome[1.5]{X}{0}{x}
\end{Compose}
\end{equation}
Furthermore, this is maximal in that there does not exist a similar equivalence for the same physical type, $\mathsfb x$, but for another pointer type, $\mathtt z$, having $N_\mathtt{z} > N_\mathtt{x}$.
\end{quote}
